AN APPEAL TO HOPKINS MEN
Defeats Black and Blue by the Score of
54 to 0— Presents Unusually Powerful Eleven—Brewer the Individual Star.

On Thanksgiving Day, before
an audience of nearly 8,000 persons that filled every available
space about Homewood Field,
Maryland State College won the
Maryland football championship
by defeating Hopkins' Varsity
eleven by the large and overwhelming score of 54 to 0. State
started the ball rolling in the first
five minutes of play by scoring
two touchdowns in quick succession, and from that time until the
close of the contest the size of
their score depended for the most
part on the time left for play.
Hopkins lost to a superior team.
At no time did the Black and
Blue threaten the visitors' goal
line. Although the teamwork of
the Black and Blue eleven was
much improved over that of last
week, the team as a whole played
with an absence of the spirit and
determination that is usually exhibited in such contests.
The overwhelming defeat of
Hopkins came as a surprise to
everyone.
It w a s generally
thought that the Black and Blue
had a strong defensive eleven that
would at least be able to hold the
visitors to a small score. However, it was soon evident that Hopkins was up against one of the
most powerful aggregations ever
seen in action on Homewood
Field. In short, from the first
blow of the whistle until the end
of the fourth quarter it was simply a walkover for the visitors.
They had a line superior to that
of Hopkins and a much superidr
backfield, so that by straight football they were able to carry the
ball down the field at will. State's
attack on Thursday consisted of
a line plunging team, and their
gains were made mostly by
delayed passes off - tackle and
through guard.
State's great victory was made
possible largely by the excellent
work of Brewer and Fletcher.
These two stellar backs were
easily the individual stars of the
contest. Brewer did most of the
ground gaining for State, ran a
kick-off for a touchdown kicked
two drop-kicks and added the deciding punch toward several other
touchdowns.
State scored three touchdowns
in the first quarter. The first
came soon after State had received the ball on the kick-off on
her own 40-yard line. Then the

The movement for undergraduate football at Hopkins has
at last blazed forth. It will come up for discussion before the
Athletic Board some time this week; the Mail Bag rings with
it; The News-Letter has devoted its entire editorial space to its
consideration. 1 his week is only the beginning; before the
question is decided, one way or the other, every phase of it
must be subjected to thorough research, every argument on
either side must be impartially weighed. Undergraduate football is a personal matter to every Hopkins man. The NewsLetter is the official organ of the Johns Hopkins University;
through its columns alone can the question be presented.
This is a personal appeal to every Hopkins Graduate, Senior,
Junior, Sophomore, and _Freshman. What do you think of
undergraduate football? Is it necessary? Is it possible? Is it
advisible? Is there an alternative? It makes no difference
whether what you have to say has been expressed before, even
in the very words which you yourself would use. It makes
no difference whether you are for undergraduate football or
against it. It makes no difference whether the letters submitted run up into the dozens—if necessary,the Mail Bag will be
extended until it fills half the paper. We want your opinion.

UNIVERSITY RECEIVES BEQUEST

INTERCLASS GAME ON SATURDAY

Will of Late Dr. Hewitt Bequeaths to
Hopkins Valuable Bacteriological Material and Specimens
and Library.

Freshmen Have Been Practising for
Two Weeks--Sophs Have Several
'Varsity Players—Hot Contest Is Expected.

Although no definite announcement has been made by the trustees of the University, it has become known that the will of the
late Joseph Henry Hewitt, M. D.,
of Princess Anne county, Va., contains a valuable bequest to the
Johns Hopkins University.
According to a clause of the
will, the bequest includes bacteriological material and specimens, as
well as valuable books, journals
and papers directly or indirectly
relating to the subject of medicine. Bookcases, a Century dictionary and an Encyclopedia Brittanica and other equipment are
also included. The bequest iS
made with the understanding that
a library shall be formed, to be
known as the departmental library of the department of pathology of the Johns Hopkins
Medical School; that this library
shall occupy a room to itself.
The bequest was made to the
University over a year ago, but
the will has not been probated
until recently. Preparations are
now going on for the transportation of the books and specimens
to the Medical School.

Following the Hopkins custom
of having the freshman-sophomore
football game on the Saturday
after Thanksgiving week, the
game will be played on Saturday,
December 9.
Coach Pfitsch has had his
freshman team out and running
through their signals for the past
couple of weeks, but since many
of the ' sophomores are on the
'Varsity squad, the 1919 team
will hold their initial practice today. Captain Schmidt has a good
fighting crowd of men under him,
as was proved last fall when they
held the fast and heavy junior
eleven, composed largely of 'Varsity men, to a scoreless tie.
The lineup will probably be as
follows:

Sophomores—Ends, Allen and
Gatchell; tackles, Schmidt and
Sonneborn; guards, Stanley and
Benson; center, Hecht; quarterback, Kirk or Wasserman; halfbacks, Meyer, Frisch and Wells;
fullback, Cox.

Holmes and Norwood; tackles,

and Weaver; center, Freedom or

Insists Upon Change in Conditions of
Debating Triangle—Hopkins Council Adheres to Former Plan.
Submits Subject.

The continuation of the debating triangle between the universities of North Carolina, Virginia
and Hopkins is still unsettled.
North Carolina, however, has signified its willingness to debate
under the old conditions, and only
Virginia is still holding out for a
change in the agreement.
The proposal which is delaying
the progress of the debates this
year is the one submitted by Virginia two weeks ago—the abolition of the plan by which neither
team of any of the three universities debated on its home ground,
and, the substitution in its place
of some arrangement by which
each institution would have at
least one team debating on its
own territory.
Hopkins' objections to this plan
are two-fold: First, the sending
away of the teams affords the de;
haters an experience and extends
the relations of the University in
a manner which would otherwise
be unobtaitiable; and, second, it
would do away with the strict impartiality of the judges, which the
present system guarantees.
It is always difficult, the Debating Council holds, to obtain men
to judge debates who will really
judge according to the strict debating qualities of the teams, and
who will ndt be unconsciously influenced one way or the other by
questions of sentiment. University professors undoubtedly form
the best judges, and, when they
are judges of a debate between
two universities, with both of
which they are absolutely unconnected, their superiority is unquestioned.
Under Virginia's
plan, such judges would be practically impossible of access,
The question which Hopkins
will submit to the other two debating councils for agreement, in
case the triangle is to be continued, has already been decided
upon. It is, "Resolved, that, constitutionality waived, legislation
providing for the compulsory arbitration of labor disputes in public utilities and prohibiting all
strikes and lockouts in such utilities should b,e enacted."
This question brings up for discussion an issue in which the entire country is vitally interested,
and one which affords ample opportunity for clear-cut debate.
The questions submitted to the
other two councils will probably
be received within the next week.

LACROSSE ORGANIZES DEC. 14
Every Prospective Player Invited to Be
Present at Meeting—Speeches to Be
Made by Past and Present
Hopkins Stars.

The organization meeting of the
1917 lacrosse team will be held
Thursday, December 14, at 5 P.
M. in the Y. AT. C. A. room in the
Civil Engineering Building. The
organization meeting marks the
official opening of the lacrosse
season at Hopkins, and anyone
who has ever played the game or
has any idea of playing is invited
to attend, whether he has definitely decided to play lacrosse
this year or not.
Freshmen especially are urged
by the management to attend the
meeting, whether they have ever
played the game before or not, as
a special squad of these men will
be organized to learn stickwork
and the principles of the game befor scrimmage work begins after
the holidays.
Capt. John C. Knipp will -preside at the meeting, and there will
be a gen er:11 discussion of the out-

look for the coming year. Manager Randolph Smith will announce the schedule, which will
be definitely completed by that
time, and Coach Reaney Wolfe
will tell of the work and the plans
for the coining year. Bill Schmeisser—"Father Bill," as he is alled
by all lacrosse then-will be present and will make a speech, as
will the other two alumni advisers of the team, Dr. Cohn and
Bobby Lowndes. Then, there will
be another speech by an alumnus
of the University, concerning
whom Captain Knipp is very
chary of giving any information.
It has been rumored, however,
that not only was he one of the
best lacrosse men who ever attended Hopkins, but that he is a
remarkably good talker as well.
A day or so after the organization meeting, lacrosse practice
will begin, with especial attention
paid to stickwork.from now until
the Christmas holidays. There
will be several sections of the
squad, with a separate day, as
mentioned above, for those who
have never played the game before.

ALL READY FOR FIRST CONCERT
Both Glee and Mandolin Clubs Are in
Fine Shape—First Concert at Phipps
Clinic, on December 19.

With an eligibility list of nearly
fifty men, with an excellent program carefully rehearsed, and
with the prospects of an unusually varied schedule, the Johns
Hopkins Combined. Musical Clubs
are ready to give their first concert at the Phipps Clinic of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital on the
night of December 19.
The response to the appeals for
singers and players has been
greater this year than ever before.
There is not a position in either
club which is not being contested,
and contested hotly. Thirty men
are to be taken on the various
trips planned for the clubs, and,
from present indications, the calibre of those men will rank exceptionally high amolig college musical organizations.
The Glee Club has been practicing every Thursday night at the
Civil Engineering Building, under
the direction of Mr. Edmund Spieker, graduate student in geology
and former editor-in-chief of THE
NEWS-LETTER. Um:ley his guidance, the club has been making
exceptional progress. Several of
the old favorites of the club, including a number of Hopkins
songs, have been practiced until
they have attained a high grade
of technical rendition, and many
new pieces have been added to the
repertoire. The University quartet, as it is now rehearsing, is
composed of Spieker, Luther
Haughton,'17 H. J. Gorman,'17;
and Robert Duncan, '18.
The Mandolin Club has been
holding its rehearsals on Monday
nights at Beethoven Hall. The
policy introduced this year of having a professional coach to train
the club is proving remarkably
satisfactory. Mr. McCauley has
not only a wide knowledge of musical instruments and of the technique of harmony, but he has also
had large experience in just such
work as he is now performing.
With his assistance, a varied program has been selected. The
leader of the club is B. S. Winchester, '17.
The schedule of the clubs has
not as yet been announced. Due
to the experience of previous
years, in which extended trips
have been planned, only to collapse at the last moment, the
Board of Managers has decided
that no promises shall be made to
the men until the arrangements
have been brought to such a point
as to absolutely insure their carrying out. Manager Gorman has let
it be known, however, that he is
at work upon several trips,
which, if present prospects are
realized, will be some of the best
which Hopkins' clubs have ever
taken.

The board of governors of the
Cotillon Club held their first
meeting of the year last week and
transacted important business for
the 1916-1917 season. Robert Merrick, '17, president of the board,
resigned because of the death of
his brother, and Richard Woodward,'18, was chosen in his place.
Stewart Egerton '18, was elected
secretary, succeeding Woodward.
With the routine business relative to clearing up all matters left
over from last year out of the
way, the board turned its attention to the coming season. The
date of the first dance was set for
Friday, December 22, with, the
second and third on Friday, February 16, and Saturday, May 12,
respectively. The first dance will
be held in the Assembly Room of
the Civil Engineering Building,
this place being decided upon
after the matter was carefully
considered and talked over with
Dean Murray P. Brush. It was
brought out that in case of an
overflow crowd, the dancers could
"trip the light fantastic" in the
surrounding corridors and hence
relieve any congestion in the main
room. An additional point in
favor of holding the dances at
Homewood was that since the
affair,is distinctly a University
one, it would be more in keeping
to hold the party in the University buildings.
McCoy Hall May be available
for the second and third dances,
but at present is unheated and
without the necessary facilities.
In case the Civil Engineering
Building room is found too small
and McCoy Hall is not at the disposal of the board, the second and
third cotillons will_ be held at
Lehman's Hall.
It is felt, however, that the new
Assembly Room will be entirely
a,dequate, with the addition of the
corridors, and that the dances
will be strictly in keeping with
the enjoyable affairs of previous
years. The one and only Louis
Fisher and his orchestra will
again render popular dancing
airs, and the "eats" will be in
keeping with the high standards
set by previous cotillons.

The continuation of the debating triangle between the universities of North Carolina, Virginia
and Hopkins is still unsettled.
North Carolina, however, has signified its willingness to debate
under the old conditions, and only
Virginia is still holding out for a
change in the agreement.
The proposal which is delaying
the progress of the debates this
year is the one submitted by Virginia two weeks ago—the abolition of the plan by which neither
team of any of the three universities debated on its home ground,
and, the substitution in its place
of some arrangement by which
each institution would have at
least one team debating on its
own territory.
Hopkins' objections to this plan
are two-fold: First, the sending
away of the teams affords the de;
haters an experience and extends
the relations of the University in
a manner which would otherwise
be unobtaitiable; and, second, it
would do away with the strict impartiality of the judges, which the
present system guarantees.

to judge debates who will really
judge according to the strict debating qualities of the teams, and
who will ndt be unconsciously influenced one way or the other by
questions of sentiment. University professors undoubtedly form
the best judges, and, when they

other two councils will probably

There is one "strong argument
against undergraduate football in
any college or university which
must be here considered—the almost inevitable danger of the upbuilding of a system of athletic
scholarships which in itself is a
serious menace to the aims and
ideals of the institution in which
it finds root. Such a menace
would be present were undergraduate football to be adopted at
Hopkins. In the desire to bring
forth winning teams, an amount,
of pressure which can hardly be
estimated would be levied upon
our Athletic Association to create
for football players who would
come to Hopkins a special fund,
which by judicious distribution
just within the margin of technical safety, would amply compensate them for their attendance. Against the evils of such a
system it is unnecessary to speak,
all the more in that the evil does

The real question, however,'is of
that very attainability—whether,
even if undergraduate football is
in itself desirable, it is practical.
And by practical is ineant not the
mere possibility of having an undergraduate team, but the possibility of having a team which
shall represent its University
worthily.

first of all is heard the 6.37, "But

of the 393 undergraduates of this

almost inevitably, means that the
increase in the size of the undergraduate department is to be consistently continued.
The next question is: Is a body
of 400 men large enough to enable
a good football team to be built
up? The answer to this question
likewise can be indicated by a
few figures. The Haverford team,
which defeated Hopkins this season, was drawn from an enrollment of 195; the Swarthmore
eleven, which, in addition to Hopkins, defeated the University of
Pennsylvania, was built up from
a total undergraduate enrollment
of 441—and Swarthmore is co-ed.
But from these figures immediately arises the query: Granted
that there are enough potential
football players at Hopkins to
form a .good team, would they
come out in sufficient 'force to
make such a team possible?
The query has reference, first,
of course, to the fact that both
Haverford and Swarthmore have
dormitories, while Hopkins has
none; that the men at those institutions, by reason of the circumstances in which they are situated, take a more active interest
in college activities than do Hopkins men. The fact that the presence of dormitories does aid—and
aid materially — in the development of a football team is incontrovertible. Yet it has been definitely announced that Hopkins
is to have a dormitory within the
near future. Also, the change in
atmosphere produced by the removal to Homewood is unquestioned.
This year there were 25 juniors,
sophomores and freshmen listed
upon the roll book of the football
manager; and, in addition, it is estimated that there were at least
10 men practicing with the team
at various times during the season who never definitely enrolled.
This would make a nucleus of approximately 35 men upon which to
build an undergraduate team next
year, irrespective of the incoming
class, and irrespective of the men
from the present three'classes who
might come out for a strictly
undergraduate team when they
would not be aroused by the appeal of a, team conducted under
the present system. And those
facts are as far as anyone can go.
Whether that nucleus would be

sufficient, how many men the
Class of 1921 will furnish for the
squad, whether the number of
those reporting for practice with
an undergraduate team who did
not come out for the present team
will be large or negligible, are all
questions which offer wide field
for discussion — questions which
can only be answered, in the first
and last cases, by the men concerned.
There is one- very important
matter connected with the possibility of undergraduate football,
however, which does permit of
definite anticipation—the matter
of daylight practice. With undergraduate football, such practice
will admittedly be possible—the
only question is whether it can
be obtained. Daylight practice
does not mean ten or twenty minutes in the twilight; it means the
release of the football - players
from laboratories at some such
time as 4 o'clock. It takes no'
deep student of football to state
that, without such practice, no
successful team can be developed,
whatever, system be employed.
With the possibility of such practice, however, which the elimination of graduate students would
insure, a determined effort can be
made, once for all, to arrange
some schedule by which the players can obtain their release at
some such time—always with the.
understanding that the work be
made up at some other time. If
the faculty is both willing and
able to work out such a schedule,
it is the opinion of THE NEWSLETTER that undergraduate football can be successful. It is upon
this one matter that the whole
question will probably be found
to hinge.
There are three possible alternatives to undergraduate football:
(a) Delay, (b) a four-year eligibility rule, (c) a three-year elgibility rule.
The first of these alternatives
is in opposition to the feeling
of the student body. There is a
general conviction, at the present
time, that whatever is going to
,be done, should be planned now.
This does not mean that we should
necessatily have undergraduate
football next year, if we are to
have it at all; it is easily conceivpble that, should the movement be successful, the Athletic
Association would desire a yearor two leeway in order to develop

'Varsity' player shrould have had

football, wherever those years

it is true it would allow the playing of those graduate students
who have not played football at
other colleges; but, at the same
time, it would not prohibit the
seeking of players among the
graduate students of the first
year. As a matter of fact, the
only change which such a rule
.would probably make in the present system would be the restriction of the search for ready-developed players to one graduate
class, instead of the larger field
which is now available.
A three-year eligibility rule
would probably accomplish the
desired end, but it would do so at
the sacrifice, for the up-building
of the team, of all the football
material which there -happens to
be in the Freshman Class — for
such a rule, of course, depends
upon the ineligibility of freshmen.
At some future time that plan
may be adopted, but it cannot be
adopted at a time when the
Freshman Class contains almost
one half of the undergraduate enrollment. To develop undergraduate teams, for the first few
years, at least, Hopkins will need
the services of every available undergraduate.
In concluding this discussion,
one fact must be emphasized:
Hopkins should take no step without a full realization of the consequences which that step entails.

every possible phase before it is

evidence of shallowness and lack
of appreciation, but in the fact
that the student body permits
such statements to go on record
unchallenged. Therein lies the
tragedy — the statements themselves are only inordinately silly.
